Submodules

StatisticsAndOptimization.gaussian_regression module

StatisticsAndOptimization.gaussian_regression.gaussian_process(x_train: ndarray[Any, dtype[Any]], y_train: ndarray[Any, dtype[Any]], x_test: ndarray[Any, dtype[Any]]) → tuple[Callable[[ndarray[Any, dtype[Any]]], tuple[ndarray[Any, dtype[Any]], ndarray[Any, dtype[Any]], float, ndarray[Any, dtype[Any]]]], Callable[[ndarray[Any, dtype[Any]]], float]][source]

Setup function for Gaussian Process Regression. This function returns a pair of callables. The callables are the following: - gaussian_process_regression (Callable): Returns mean regression, standard deviation, log marginal likelihood, and covariance matrix - cost_fnc (Callable): Returns only log marginal likelihood, intended use is for hyperparameter optimization

Primary reference material: https://gaussianprocess.org/gpml/chapters/RW2.pdf

Parameters:

  • x_train (NDArray) – Training data set

  • y_train (NDArray) – Training data set y points

  • x_test (NDArray) – Desired test points to evaluate

Returns:

Function to evaluate Gaussian Process Regression for the training data set on test data points as a function of a length scale, kernel noise parameter, and evaluation noise parameter. # TODO: Are kernel noise parameter and evaluation noise parameter consistent

Return type:

Callable

StatisticsAndOptimization.gaussian_regression.kernel(a: ndarray[Any, dtype[Any]], b: ndarray[Any, dtype[Any]], length: float = 1.0, signal_variance2: float = 1.0, type: str = 'SE') → ndarray[Any, dtype[Any]][source]

The kernel function used for Gaussian Process Regression. In this case, a square exponential covariance function is implemented.

Parameters:

  • a (float) – Point a of the kernel

  • b (float) – Point b of the kernel

  • length (float, optional) – Length scale. Defaults to 1.

  • signal_variance2 (float, optional) – Signal variance squared. Defaults to 1.

Returns:

Kernel evaluation

Return type:

float

StatisticsAndOptimization.gaussian_regression.main()[source]
StatisticsAndOptimization.gaussian_regression.normalization(x: ndarray[Any, dtype[Any]], y: ndarray[Any, dtype[Any]]) → tuple[ndarray[Any, dtype[Any]], ndarray[Any, dtype[Any]], float, float][source]

Normalize a set of x and y points. This is required for effective optimization as hyperparameters like step size will be significantly impacted.

Parameters:

  • x (NDArray) – Array of x points

  • y (NDArray) – Array of y points

Returns:

Normalized array of x points NDArray: Normalzied array of y points float: Scalar used to normalize x points float: Scalar used to normalized y points

Return type:

NDArray

StatisticsAndOptimization.gaussian_regression.simulated_annealing(x_0: ndarray[Any, dtype[Any]], cost_fnc: Callable[[ndarray[Any, dtype[Any]]], float], temperature_0: float = 1000, mu: float = 0.99, step_size: float = 0.02) → tuple[ndarray[Any, dtype[Any]], float][source]

Simulated annealing algorithm. Reference: Kirkpatrick, Gelatt, Vecchi (1983), “Optimization by Simulated Annealing”

Parameters:

  • x_0 (NDArray) – Starting point.

  • cost_fnc (Callable) – Function to evaluate.

  • temperature_0 (float, optional) – Initial temperature. Defaults to 1000.

  • mu (float, optional) – Rate of cooling after each iteration. Defaults to 0.99.

  • step_size (float, optional) – Step size to explore space. Defaults to .02.

Returns:

Optimizer float: Optima

Return type:

NDArray
